item.title: Use DateOnly and TimeOnly with EF Core 6, 7 & 8 and Azure SQL / SQL Server
item.description: SQL Server added the date (and time) data types in 2008 - now, 15 years later, you can finally take full advantage of these data types with Entity Framework Core and save at least 50% disk space and bandwidth with date.

item.title: Elevate Your .NET Testing Strategy #4: InMemory vs Repository pattern
item.description:
In the ever-evolving landscape of software development, the way we manage data is paramount to performance and efficiency. In the context of C#/.NET, InMemory databases have long been a staple for various applications. However, the emergence of SQLite in-memory databases offers exciting new prospects.

item.title: An Intuition for Logarithms · On the Joy of Problems
Collecting Prometheus metrics from multi-process web servers, the Ruby case
item.description: In Prometheus, metrics collection must follow concrete rules. It is a challenge with multi-process web servers where each scrape might reach a different instance of the app which holds a local copy of the metric. In this article I describe a rebellious solution of which combines StatsD with Prometheus.

item.title: Waking up my NAS remotely using Tailscale
item.description: I recently bought a NAS (a TerraMaster F4-423 if you’re curious). My main uses cases for it are: Plex media server, Samba share, Resilio Sync target. I wanted all that to be accessible from anywhere so I installed Tailscale on the NAS and made it join my tailnet.

item.title: GameRoy: JIT compilation in High-Accuracy Game Boy Emulation
item.description: Over the past two years, I have spent a lot of time working on my Game Boy emulator, GameRoy. It has reached a good point, where it has a GUI interface (including a debugger and disassembler) and passes numerous tests (comparable to some of the most accurate emulators). I even made a port to Android!
